docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration warned today that failure by Congress to pass an economic recovery package would endanger the prospects for a rebound next year, but it offered no compromises to break a partisan deadlock on Capitol Hill. In an interview, President Bush's top economic policy advisers said they remained optimistic about reaching a deal based on the administration's proposal for a new round of tax cuts.

headline.main: Bush Advisers Say Congress Must Act Now on Economy

docs.abstract: Lawrence B Lindsey, R Glenn Hubbard, Sec Paul H O'Neill and Mitchell E Daniels, Bush administration's top economic policy aides, warn Congress must pass economic recovery package or endanger prospects for 2002 rebound, interview; offer no compromises to break partisan deadlock in Congress; express optimism about reaching deal based on Bush's tax cut proposals; Democrats hold Bush should be more active in brokering compromise (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green warned yesterday that the $4-to-6-billion deficit that the city is expected to face next year is its greatest fiscal crisis since it nearly went bankrupt in the 1970's, and he said that he has ''the experience in government to make hard choices, tell the public hard truths and take the heat.'' For the most part, Mr. Green avoided talking about specific cuts that he would make if he was elected mayor, except to reiterate his support for a temporary hiring freeze on all city workers other than teachers, police officers and firefighters. Although he still spoke about paying teachers more and hiring more of them to shrink class sizes, he made it clear that such goals would now take longer to achieve.

headline.main: Green Says City Faces Fiscal Crisis As Bad as in 70's

docs.lead_paragraph: Anthem's shares rose on their first day of trading after the provider of Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance raised $1.78 billion in its initial public offering. Anthem, which twice increased its offering to meet demand from investors, rose $4.90, or 14 percent, to $40.90. The company, which insures almost eight million people in eight states, sold 48 million shares, or 47 percent of the company. The shares were sold at $36 each, the high end of the expected $33 to $37 range.

headline.main: Health Insurer's Shares Rise on First Day

docs.abstract: Shares of Anthem Inc, provider of Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance, rise on first day of trading after raising $1.78 billion in its initial public offering (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An optometrist has been convicted of defrauding 29 insurance companies out of $200,000. A jury on Monday found that the optometrist, John Amabile, 39, of Spring Lake Heights, billed companies for some 600 procedures he never performed, said Paul Loriquet, a spokesman for the sate attorney general's office. Mr. Amabile faces up to 10 years in prison and $190,000 in fines, and is to be sentenced on Dec. 14. Mr. Amabile's lawyer, Michael Wilbert, was unavailable for comment, his office said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Optometrist Found Guilty

byline.original: By Steve Strunsky (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: State officials in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey have deployed more National Guard troops at transportation centers, water supplies and nuclear power plants after the federal government's warning of possible additional terrorist attacks. In New York, the Pataki administration said it would put more than 400 Guard troops on active duty for 90 days, the longest call-up in decades, starting tomorrow to help patrol train stations, airports, bridges and tunnels. By the end of this week, more than 1,500 guardsmen will be stationed at sites in and around New York City, including the city's upstate reservoirs and the state's four nuclear power facilities, said Gov. George E. Pataki.

headline.main: States Assign More Troops After U.S. Terror Warning
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NATIONAL GUARD

docs.abstract: State officials in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey deploy more National Guard troops at transportation centers, water supplies and nuclear power plants in response to federal warning of possible additional terrorist attacks; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Rite Aid drugstore chain said today that it would pay New Jersey $150,000 to settle a state lawsuit over a past policy that allowed pharmacists to overcharge certain customers for prescription drugs. In the settlement between the Rite Aid Corporation and the State Division of Consumer Affairs, the company acknowledged that its pharmacists had arbitrarily raised prices for customers not covered by insurance or group discounts.

headline.main: Rite Aid Settles State Lawsuit Over Pharmacy Overcharging

docs.lead_paragraph: Minutes after the second plane hit the World Trade Center, hospitals in Manhattan activated their disaster plans: They canceled elective surgery, discharged stable patients and closed walk-in clinics, emptying their beds to await the thousands of expected casualties. But those patients never arrived. And in the following weeks, the fallout from Sept. 11 -- including transportation difficulties and telephone failures -- kept regular patients away, and some hospitals stood one-quarter empty. Once anthrax hit, panicked New Yorkers in search of Cipro flooded emergency rooms, costing time and resources but not needing to be admitted and therefore generating little income.

headline.main: Sept. 11 Exacts an Economic Toll From the Hospitals of New York

docs.abstract: Article discusses economic toll on New York City hospitals from Sept 11 terrorist attacks; minutes after second plane hit World Trade Center, hospitals in Manhattan activated their disaster plans: they canceled elective surgery, discharged stable patients and closed walk-in clinics, emptying their beds to await thousands of expected casualties that never arrived; transportation dificulties and telephone failures in weeks since have kept regular patients away; in six tramatic weeks, hospitals in New York City have lost $367 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There has long been a disturbing paradox associated with being a good driver. To know how to respond to a host of difficult and often unpredictable traffic situations and hazardous road conditions, a driver needs experience behind the wheel. But in getting such experience, many new drivers, especially teenagers, end up having accidents that in all likelihood could have been avoided -- if they had had more experience.

headline.main: Reducing the Risks for Teenage Drivers

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on reducing high crash risk for inexperienced teenage drivers; cites success of graduated licensing systems adopted by many states, which phase in full driving privileges for teenagers over two or more years, in reducing accidents, injuries and deaths; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: There has long been a disturbing paradox associated with being a good driver. To know how to respond to a host of difficult and often unpredictable traffic situations and hazardous road conditions, a driver needs experience behind the wheel.    But...

docs.lead_paragraph: Until anthrax spores started spreading through the mail, few people gave much thought to the minuscule particles that drift almost invisibly in the atmosphere, infiltrate buildings and plunge deep into lungs. Not so for environmental scientists, who have spent decades studying the physics and physiology of particles very much like those in the most dangerous forms of biological weaponry. From the coal dust that causes black lung disease to the bacteria-laden droplets that spread Legionnaires' disease to second-hand cigarette smoke and plain old air pollution, particles from about 0.05 microns to 10 or 20 microns in size have long been at the focus of those scientists' attention. A micron is a millionth of a meter, or an inch divided into 25,400 parts.

headline.main: Particles Are Tiny, but Damage Can Be Great

docs.abstract: Environmental scientists have long studied physics and physiology of particles 0.05 microns to 10 or 20 microns in size, tiny particles that crop up in environmental science and germ weaponry because once released they can stay aloft almost indefinitely, seep into buildings and be inhaled by people; peculiar microscopic physics shared by all these particles insures some will be deposited deep in lungs, where great damage can be done; knowledge is freely available in unclassified literature; environmental scientists cite bioterrorism threat as added reason to improve quality of indoor air with powerful filters and other methods; diagrams (M)
docs.snippet: Until anthrax spores started spreading through the mail, few people gave much thought to the minuscule particles that drift almost invisibly in the atmosphere, infiltrate buildings and plunge deep into lungs. Not so for environmental scientists, who...

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, heretic groups of corporate managers, technologists and consultants have promoted the idea that a decentralized network of workplaces might serve the needs of employees and companies better than a large central headquarters. But it is an idea that has usually failed to catch on, even as the necessary technology has become ubiquitous and affordable. Managers, it turns out, like to see employees working. Co-workers know that value emerges from impromptu hallway meetings. And for the accounting departments, multiplying overhead costs by multiple locations seemed improvident.

headline.main: Breaking Up the Central Office; Staffs Make a Virtue of Necessity

docs.abstract: Corporations, spurred by confluence of crisis and technology, are taking closer look at so-called distributed workplace and studying handful of corporations that have dispersed workers; sampling of companies that have dispersed workers, including some displaced from World Trade Center; table; photos (M)
